Award.AwardTitle: The Purest Dark Matter Halos and the Processes of Galaxy Evolution
Award.AbstractNarration:
A galaxy contains a mixture of gas, stars and dark matter. The gas and stars emit light, making them easy to study. But the dark matter is, well, dark: It does not emit light; so, it is difficult to study. Theories of galaxy formation try to account for the mixtures of gas, stars and dark matter in galaxies of all types. Recently, a new type of galaxy was discovered, the so-called ultra-diffuse galaxies (UDGs). These galaxies contain dark matter but, it seems, little else. This makes UDGs great places to test theories of galaxy formation. UDGs could also provide clues about the nature of dark matter. The race is on to find more UDGs, and the team has an ambitious plan to win the race. They will analyze ongoing surveys that cover huge swaths of the sky at optical wavelengths. The team will sift through the data to find UDGs. Then, they will study the properties of the UDGs. Senior team members will train junior team members. The team will partner with the Mount Lemmon Science Center in Arizona. There, the team will run a workshop for middle and high school teachers, plus host observatory visits by teachers and their students. The team's research will be featured in the workshop.

The team will use deep, publicly-available imaging surveys to (1) produce a catalog of UDGs, (2) determine the global properties of UDGs over all environments, (3) contrast UDGs with normal galaxies, and (4) measure the profiles of the dark matter halos of UDGs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We have studied the largest, most diffuse galaxies in the nearby universe with the goal of better understanding the procesess that form galaxies and the nature of dark matter. To do this, we undertook compiling the largest catalog in existence of such galaxies that spans all type of environments in which galaxies are found. This involved taking existing electronic images of roughly 1/3 of the entire sky, developing techniques to remove the easily visible objects (stars, bright galaxies, image defects), blurring the images to increase our sensitivity to diffuse objects, identifying the candidates, and then classifying the candidates. The last step we do with artificial intelligence techniques to distinguish the type of galaxies we are searching for from other sources of diffuse emission.

As a result of this work, we now have the largest catalog of such objects across environments and are poised to expand that catalog more than ten-fold. With this catalog, and follow-up observations at optical wavelengths using the world's largest telescopes and other large surveys, at ultraviolet wavelengths using one of NASA's great observatories, and at radio wavelengths using the Green Bank Observatory, we have reached a number of conclusions. We have found that these galaxies are ubiquitous in all environments, that their structure (size, shape) does not depend on environment but that the rate at which they form stars does, that the galaxies in more isolated environments have been forming stars for most of their lives, probably in short bursts, while those in denser environments stopped forming stars long ago, that the amount of neutral hydrogen gas in these galaxies is related to the galaxy size in such a way that favors a model in which these galaxies undergo a series of expansions and collapses, and that these galaxies range in size, including some that are as large as the largest normal galaxies (and are therefore probably comparably massive).

In the course of this research, we have involved two Ph.D. thesis students, two postdoctoral researchers, and over ten undergraduate students. As such, this work has helped train the next generation of STEM experts. We have also continued our collaboration with the Tucson Unified School District's (TUSD) Regional Science Center (RSC), and the Pima County Schools Superintendent's Office STEMAZing Project in the Mt. Lemmon Sky Center's science teacher professional development program. Finally, we have joined efforts with a Spanish-language astronomy public lecture series to extend astronomy's reach in our local community.
